keyTakeAways: A runner from New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run.
Halloran sustained serious injuries, including a bitten-off arm and leg wounds, requiring multiple surgeries and long-term recovery.
Bear attacks in Japan have risen sharply, with over 100 injuries and at least seven deaths reported this year — the highest since 2006.
Climate change is linked to increased bear forays into human-populated areas as traditional food sources vanish due to disrupted flowering and pollination.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the surge in attacks.
Residents are taking precautions such as using bells, loud music, or bear spray to deter bears.
Halloran plans to return to running in the woods, citing community support and a desire to reconnect with nature despite lasting trauma.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In early October 2025, Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run. The attack left him with severe injuries, including a bitten-off arm and leg wounds, requiring multiple surgeries and extensive rehabilitation. This incident reflects a broader crisis in Japan, where bear attacks have surged—over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year—due to climate change disrupting traditional bear food sources. The Japanese government has responded by introducing tougher measures to manage bear populations, while residents adopt preventive tactics like bear spray or loud noises. Halloran, despite the trauma, remains determined to return to nature and running, highlighting both the vulnerability of rural communities to wildlife encroachment and the human resilience in the face of such danger.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
